Lingering I gazed upon that ghastly crowd,</br>And there behold what I can scarce relate,</br>Upon my sole avouch, without a cloud</br>Of witness behind: — my steady mate</br>Unshrinking Conscience, under whose breast-plate</br>Of truth, and sentiment serene and pure,</br>A man may stand, and freely face his fate—</br>She urges me to tell all out — secure</br>Of the event, as one who of his facts is sure.

Certain I saw, and still, methinks, I view</br>A body moving on without a head,</br>As moved the others of that wretched crew—</br>The hand that head held firmly, — and instead</br>Of lamp or lantern, the blind feet it led</br>Grasped by the locks: — it glared on us, and "woe,"</br>It cried, "woe, woe," — as on the spectre sped—</br>So here were two in one, and one in two,</br>By what mysterious link, who linked alone can know.

Soon as the shape right at the bridge's base</br>Stood fixed, the arm was stretched to its height,</br>Raising close up to me this grisly face,</br>That not a word might 'scape me — "Here's a sight</br>Of horror for thee, whate'er living wight</br>Thou art, who visitest these seats of pain:—</br>Hast met with damned ghost in such a plight</br>As this? — But wouldst thou give to earth again</br>My name and story, (thus the phantom spoke me plain,)

"Know that my name is Bertrand, he of Born,</br>Who to King John gave counsels of such guilt,</br>That son 'gainst father raised rebellion's horn—</br>Not worse Achitophel, who hilt to hilt</br>Set Absolom and David in foul tilt:</br>And thus, by retribution stern, but just,</br>As I the bond of nature's junction spilt</br>Dissevering hearts that rest on sacred trust,</br>So is this plotting head dissevered from its bust."</br>
